user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_unlock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /* Restore previous cancellability state */
        pthread_setcancelstate(OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState, NULL);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl:
OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobalData_t OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal
...
#define BSP_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. pthread_mutex_unlock has prototype int pthread_mutex_unlock(pthread_mutex_t *); it must modify the mutex state, so the parameter is correctly a non-const pointer. Passing &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex does not violate Rule 8.13. (A violation would occur only if the pointer could be const-qualified but is not — not the case here.)
